commentBody:
Said one banker to another, "We were mint for each other."

(They keep things interest-ing.)

Took a while to get started but one clue soon caused the rest to fall. 
Completely forgot about the theme until the end…
Some obscure proper nouns caused me trouble. And the juggling clue for Noone was quite convoluted
Overall, good puzzle, but I prefer a running theme throughout the grid itself and not as a post puzzle solve. This is not a complaint, just a personal preference.

TENDER GREEN KALE, DOUGH, CHEDDAR - it might’ve been a pizza in the making?

Anyone else ever experience the hilarious situation where management decides to give the employees a pizza party instead of their deserved pay bump? 

But I got the right theme in the end, because Sid Sivakumar would never dream of doing such a lowdown thing, least of all with a kale pizza.

Interesting way to introduce screwing.  Are we getting more risque these days?  
Would have loved to see moolah, but no complaints - just some random thoughts on a fun solve and fine distraction.

Sid Sunday!  I was just thinking the other day that we haven’t had a puzzle from him in months. 

This was a smooth and steady solve.  I caught onto the theme with GODDAUGHTER, and  enjoyed the discovery of each PAY BUMP along the way. And I’m enriched by having learned some new phrases. 

I laughed at the “Turning some heads” clue. 

Fun crossing of I AM, I CLOUD, and AYE.

Thanks, Sid. I eagerly look forward to the super mega!

Perfect pregame puzzle for West Coast Warriors fans (game on at 5 p.m.).  I had a ball, but without the helpful crosses it would have been too tough to trip through so quickly (well, sort of quickly).  A thoroughly enjoyable puzzle, with a crafty mix of straightforward clues and tough ones.  

Thank you, Sid Sivakumar, for putting me in such a good mood. Just the thing for a Saturday afternoon!  (Puzzle 19 sounds terrifying.)

Hi Sid,

Thanks for yet another remarkable construction (and fourth Sunday in a row). You were an MD/PhD student at Wash U for your NYT XWP debut on June 22, 2020. The puzzles have been great; how are the degrees coming along?

Best wishes!

I got my gold star after a very long hunt for my error.


Still amazed I found it, and I think it's a legit Natick.


At first I had astronaut MAy crossing CONGRUENCy

Any puzzle featuring a FRENCH PRESS is an UDDER delight.
I keep wanting to dook BE AT EASE to BE A TEASE.

Nice job, Sid.

Can we just have a puzzle please without all the other nonsense?
Sorry I but i am tired of trying to solve three layers above.
Excellent Sunday puzzle ! Was definitely not expecting to see Trisha Krishnan feature in an NYT puzzle - that was a nice surprise :)

Great puzzle, but I have a question. Why would it be ALASKA PENINSULA, and not ALASKAN PENINSULA? ty :)


-- xoxo MARLO

NY to Sydney Australia. 22 hours. I’ve done it. 
What am I missing with the Singapore/NY clue? Not the longest. 18 hours.

Confidently plopped in “Aleutian Islands” for 23A.

Oops.
Satisfying puzzle, but not as much as watching the Dodgers crush the Yankees.

Kale is a euphemism for cash?  Since when?  I'm pretty old and have never heard that.  Lettuce and cabbage, sure.  Never kale.

Anyway, decent easy-going Sunday, and another classic "why did this bother to have a theme" situation.  It didn't really add much and wasn't helpful in solving.

For a while there I really wanted "device with a plunger" to contain "parachute" (the plunger being the person) but alas.  Just like Caitlin, it just took me too long to get French press, even as I've been a regular user.

Not much else to say.  At least it had more verve and inspiration than yesterday's.  Nice little puzzle.

/not looking forward to the inevitable carping about including BLM, sigh

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

Alas, after an hour of solving and a thorough checking, I could not find my mistake. LENdTO was a valid answer, and I could not think of TAG as the crossing.

As for the theme, I don't like themes on Thursday and Sunday that make the solving easier instead of harder. In this case, if the shading and squares were not there, the solving would have been the same without the advantage of using the theme to gain extra letters more quickly

Thanks to the puzzle constructor! I managed to solve this without any lookups or clues, and in that satisfying process have also learned many new things. I have heard of the GUTENBURG bible but didn't know they invented the printing press; RUMBALL sounds like something i'd love to try one day; and I was stumped for a few minutes at the end with SIs/sARQ. In my region, root beer is A&W, I wonder how BARQ tastes like compared to it. 

Very apt puzzle theme for near the end of the year! Inflation ain't kind, hope everyone gets a huge PAY BUMP!
I don’t usually come to the comments until I’ve gotten a star but I filled the whole thing in and checked it twice so here I am to find out what I’m missing. Sigh. They should give me a raise.

This puzzle was right on the money.  It was an especially satisfying solve for me because I finished without any typos for once (after having to chase down three after struggling through yesterday’s challenge).  I solved this one without paying any attention to the circles, and only recognized the monetary theme after finishing.  The fact this one could be completed without any resort to “gimmickry,” while at the same time including some bonus wordplay and construction legerdemain, provided a little something for both of the two main classes of puzzle solvers.  Here’s hoping everybody found something to like here.

I started solving crosswords earlier this year. I started doing all the Mondays in the archives for past couple of years, then made my way down the days of the week. I am SO CLOSE to solving Sundays without lookups...there's always a couple each of the past few weeks.

I was feeling like today would be the day, but FLUE and LENT TO tripped me up. ARGG.
I've never heard anyone call money KALE before
I enjoyed this puzzle but I never did figure out the secred coded message. I assume it has something to do with drinking Ovaltine, but it was too faint on my screen to make out.

Enjoyed the puzzle, even if it took me a bit to figure out the relationship of the theme words (“Kale” threw me off).

I have a minor quibble with 9D.  EPI would not be used as an informal word for epidural (at least, I am assuming that is what it is supposed to be short for).  In the medical world, “epi” generally refers to “epinephrine” which could be used in a delivery room, but not routinely.

ODESSA being clued as a city in Texas is a great example of why these puzzles can be very hard for a fluent but foreign English speaker with a lot of knowledge about the world. To me that is and always will be an Ukrainian city, featured in many European works of culture and in recent years, tragically, in the news...
I laughed out loud at NOONE. Especially crossed with STONER.
Gotta try BARQ's root beer now -- after adding 30 minutes to today's solve, it better be worth it!
A Monday-level puzzle with a goiter....

20A, just retriggered a memory of the best RUM BALL I ever had.  Coincidentally, it was at Cafe Europa in Anchoage ALASKA in 1999.  

I think about it often.

At 59 A, why is AMA the solution to "Q&A format"
At 81A, why is THE the solution to "Word following a comma in an alphabetized list"
Thanks for any help!

Sid has the chops.  He has the chops, in his themeless puzzles, to clue at the highest level, with wit and guile.  Today his skill in building a themed puzzle really shines.  Look at what he had to do:
•	Find theme answers that would accommodate the pay bump words.
•	Because of symmetry requirements, three pairs of these answers had to have an equal number of letters.
•	That “bump” letter above the theme answer, greatly restricts what the vertical answer that includes it can be.
•	Theme answers had to be chosen and placed in a certain order to make the gray-lettered PAY BUMP happen.

Sid made it work.  On top of all this, Sid spaced nine NYT debuts answers pretty evenly around the grid, giving it pop.  Terrific build.

My fill-in included a big wow moment when I simultaneously saw and grokked the theme elements.  It also included getting two out-of-my-wheelhouse long answers – FREQUENCY SHIFT and MOOD CONGRUENCE – which happified my brain on several levels.  And I loved seeing all the long-o enders: EL PASO, BONGO, TITO, AMMO, OSSO, ECHO, DITTO, DYNAMO, EURO, and wannabe DITTOS.

Thus, a splendid outing, as I’ve come to expect with Sunday in the box with Sid.  Thank you, sir!
How is this a theme?? I totally disregarded the circles and shades and solved in just under 20m. I'm not even going to review the grid to figure out the message.

Well, that took less brain-power than I would have liked. But leaves me the energy to whip up a batch of Kale-Cheddar Bread: https://tinyurl.com/2xpm6abd * chefs tips: 1) Make sure your kale is still nice and GREEN, but your cheddar isn't. 2) Preheat the oven, and get the batter in right away, lest the chemical leavening not RAISE the loaves . Here's a little playlist to enjoy while baking, from Jamaica, Australia, and Estonia, respectively: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=og2OqUvdeFY https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LgtO4dxfwhQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XsT5qzUq4WE *link only included as an illustration, as I generally contemn all recipes from on-line amateur food-bloggers
I had sis instead of SIB for the longest time. Couldn’t find the mistake, since I’ve never heard of the root beer. Lovely puzzle overall!

Fun puzzle. Just short of my Sunday best and about half of my average, which is an improvement over recent days. The upper third, in particular, came together very smoothly. Never heard of either KALE or CHEDDAR as SLANG for money, but I also didn't use the theme for any solutions, so no harm there. I had no idea the juggling record was as high as fourteen. In honor of that answer, here's a video of one often overlooked element of the great W.C. Fields's talents: https://youtu.be/ytgPGr6JhLo?si=D82L650KkydU3tfM A few temporary traps for me: trailer before USEDCAR, Oahu before MAUI, megaTON before KILOTON. Thanks!

Just finished Saturday's puzzle.

Was filling in the puzzle at about the expected Saturday speed and probably would've beat my average time had I not had filled in something wrong.  

First off, TIL PLOSIVES which certainly was a roadblock to finding my puzzle problems.
Secondly, not being from NYC, and somewhat ignorant of baseball details, I was convinced that 18D had to me METa or METh.  
Thirdly, I had no clue who the "Noted name in lithographs" was, and was trying to work with IkEa.

Was starting to entertain the idea of reveal puzzle, when the third, and correct, option for "Subject of the 2021 documentary 'Once Upon a Time in Queens'" popped into my head.

I'll take the win, even if it did take a bit longer than average.

Onto Sunday.
Project GUTENBERG is a source for 74,000 free eboooks. I have found a couple of out-of-print books I wanted to read. The site also has audio books.

As someone who works in labor and delivery, “epi” would refer to epinephrine, not an epidural. Definitely not something we want to be giving in the delivery room.

Furthermore, an epidural is not an injection, it is a continuous infusion. 

I’ve never commented before, but this clue was extremely frustrating in its inaccuracy.

It was tough enough to accept that an HBO subscription was a requirement for completing the NYT crossword. Now I need to know which streaming service I need to buy to brush up on my South Indian cinema.

Welp....I hoe Sid knows I love him and admire his works, overall, but this puzzle...meh.  
That was a lot of work (much use of the magnifying glass), and while the long entries were rather interesting--and probably debuts--, the other fill was not of equal quality.  I am still cudgeling my brains to 'GET' 81A.  Pedestrian clues/entries.

Everyone who has heard of money referred to as KALE, please raise your hands....  I thought not.  DITTO with CHEDDAR.  (I was waiting for other cheeses...)

And it's not the time shift...I managed it nicely, although my "atomic clock" hasn't quite adjusted itself.
Okay, the pancakes are almost here....TTFN.

NOONE was a gimme for me, but I thought it too obscure for most. Few outside the profession have even heard of Roderick Noone, although among the cognoscenti he is regarded as having been perhaps the world’s greatest juggler.

This is the second time they've incorrectly clued "KILOTON" as a unit of force. Kiloton is a unit of mass - not force, not power. Get it together editors!

Regardless, I enjoyed the solve today with my freshly brewed mug of FRENCH PRESS.

As someone who spends his life in 'shallow pursuits', I searched for slang terms for money. My new favorite, which I had not known,is 'Dead Presidents'.

(Note: I owe 'shallow pursuits ' to the comment today by Andrzej , in which he described a life of 'idleness and shallow pursuits', which I now plan to use in my obituary)
Brilliant, but too much on the “mechanics’ for my Sunday.

this one took me minute, i don't know if i'm mad that it was hard (it's sunday--what did i expect?) or mad at some of the clues (looking at you 30A, 103A, 119A) but i'm not feeling very satisfied for finishing it 😂
A painstaking construction feat that adds nothing to the solving experience.

I love a Sid puzzle. It has that certain je ne sais quoi that I enjoy in my crosswords. 

Nice theme, tight, good fill, excellent cluing. We'll have to wait for Crocodile Rock.  Thanks Sid!

As always, once I realized that the tiny little circles didn't need to be changed or manipulated by me in any way, I solved this as a pleasant if less-than-exciting themeless.  I then took a brief look to see if I could see what was going on without any undue effort.  And, yes, with the help of the title I saw the KALE and the CASH and the TENDER and all the rest of it.  

Yawn.

It would have been the exact same puzzle for me without any tiny little circles and without any money appearing at all.

Am I the laziest person on the blog?  The least curious?  Don't answer that.   But at least you can say that I'm not greedy or over-focused on money.  

I did think that the "Moved across the aisle" clue was world-class.
Is there any way to see the title of the puzzle when solving on iPad?

The first "raised" answer I got was D(O)UGH, and I assumed that the raised answers were all going to be "things that rise."

The second raised answer I got was KA(L)E, and I thought, "KALE doesn't rise!  I guess they are just random words."

It wasn't until I had finished the puzzle that I could see the theme of the raised answers, not to mention the PAY BUMP.

This puzzle works in so many ways!  Well done, Sid Sivakumar!

I thought this was a fine puzzle, but I am no connoisseur (thank you spellcheck).

I even filled in a couple of squares using the theme.

I was glad the Indian star had an easy name to suss out with the gentle crossings.

I will admit, though, that one or two answers were unknown to me even after correctly filling them in.

I had state-dependent (minus the hyphen) instead of MOOD CONGRUENCE. It fits! A state-dependent memory returns when you are in the same context, which includes emotion - and, interestingly, degree of intoxication...

It's so embarrassing to be probably the only person here who doesn't know this, but was it in  "Police Academy 3: Back in Training" or was it "Police Academy 7: Yes, Seriously 7" that he invented the printing press?

A great puzzle with so much joy in finding what seemed to be really obtuse phrases.

But I can't really enjoy that feeling since once again, a perfectly completed puzzle does not get identified - "at least one letter is incorrect", a running clock and not even a blue star.

Is this the best an icon like the NYT can do?  I've contacted support when this happens at least 5 or 6 times in the last few months.  The fix is not really a fix.  I'm to Clear and then Reveal and let them know I've done so.  A couple of days later, they manually mark it as solved.  I have made all the silly things on my PC that were suggested (with most of that coming from a script, and doing so could not have caused a problem) and yet right now I'm at about a 50% chance of the thing working properly.

Really, NYT?  You charge people for this? Refund request upcoming as soon as I can find the right place to make it.  I'm going to miss you all and the puzzles have always been the standard.

I never look at the puzzle's theme before solving. I work the puzzle on an android phone and the theme doesn't show up anywhere. After I'm done I read the recap and comments and a lot of the time the theme, had I known it, wouldn't have helped anyway.
Assuming that any previous references to 26A have been scrubbed, I'll just OPINE that the crossing 1D would have been appropriately clued as, "Partner of smash."

As I get older, I have ever more to still google up, even after reading the Column. Today that included FRENCH PRESS and WHOOSH BUTTON (the latter left me in the dark; I only found stuff about sound effects), as well as IMDB and its cross AMA. In fact, I had to run exactly half the alphabet to get that M. I don't know GTA either. HAVA NA?ILA is fairly familiar, but I had to run a few letters for that G as well.

After finishing in 12:04:12, which did include a slightly lengthened night's sleep and a good breakfast, I'm not curious enough to go to the effort of looking those guys up.
This was SO GOOD! Thanks!

Sad to say Sid that I'm not a huge fan of this puzzle. I thought your longest entries clues were awkward or silly, and too easy. A lot of the crosses were trite and stale. Plus the theme seemed irrelevant, like an afterthought.
Re: "Can I have a Raise."  The word "can" means to be physically able.  The expression you are looking for is "May I have a Raise?"  May means, to be allowed.  (My mother taught fourth grade.)
I've never heard of KALE as a synonym for money, and was sure that was what was holding up my solve music, but it turned out the errant squares were elsewhere in the puzzle. Cute theme, regardless.

It was a Sunday that rolled along nicely. No lookups, about half average. 
Thanks to the time change, A) I was out walking before 7, and B) 1 pm is the 12th hour on my Apple watch stand ring, so I can sit on the couch for the rest of the day. 
I REALLY want a rum ball!

Staring at my finished puzzle for 1/2 hour - even ‘cheated’ by comparing it to the subscriber key.  They look identical and yet it tells me, something is amiss.  Don’t want to say good bye to my 3  year streak… :(

Finished quickly, almost, then got held up for another 10 minutes by a snarl in one spot resulting from having MOODCONflUENCE. Which was definitely not playing nicely with my answer for 82A. 

And what was that down? URGeon? URGeif? Couldn't be. Nothing beginning Re_ would have been a challenge for my grandmother, the expert tailor. 

So I went back and sussed out the theme. Which did not help. 

Gave myself a real dope slap when I finally "saw" the answer. It all seems so obvious now. Thank you, Sid and Joel!

Struggled at first but finally opened the puzzle up by trying the edges until the SW brought some revelation things. Never really grokked the theme as usual but finished this interesting test rather quickly for me on a Sunday. However, no gold star & no celebratory music. Did a "reveal" which incorrectly claimed that my a at the end of 84 across was incorrect. Woe is me?

Mr. Sivakumar, you never disappoint, what with the high caliber of your puzzles. Every. Single. Time.

Solving this one put me in the highest vibrational FREQUENCY, which is claimed to be the one of love.

The misdirects pushed my brain  out of its comfort zone, but were gentle enough for pleasant ahas.

Oh, and the construction! Fantastic! 

As usual, I forgot to read the title until I was done, and so, despite the gimmuck not helping me with the fill, I was able to go back to the grid and take it in, admiring it, enraptured.

I'll try my best to keep with me this lovely feeling you've provided as we head into a week of everyone everywhere holding their breath.

Thank you!

Another clever puzzle from Sid, that I finally got the theme on after finishing and looking the puzzle over. It did solve pretty quickly, so I kind of wished that it had taken more effort and time.

Thanks, Sid!

If I were still working, I wouldn’t want to get a pay raise only to have it go back down. Might the theme have worked better if the synonyms/slang for money had been on a diagonal, rising continuously from the left to the right?

I was also slightly put off by the overall grid design, particularly the large areas of black squares that isolate the NE and SW corners.

But it was nice to see so many debut words, surprising as it is that no previous puzzle has had RUM BALL (betcha can’t eat just one), GODDAUGHTER, FREQUENCY SHIFT, FRENCH PRESS or CIVIC-MINDED. MOOD CONGRUENCE is new to me and nice to know.
In Lerwick, in the Shetland Islands, you can buy tshirts bearing a map of the islands with the rest of the uk in a small box at the bottom. I wonder if something similar is available in San Juan.

since Will Shortz retired, the Sunday crossword has taken a serious turn toward "not fun anymore". It used to be fun to work Sundays' puzzle. No more.  they've gotten too far out, much more difficult to work, with confusing confituartions, 'Jeopardy-like" clues that require a lawyer/nerd to answer. Just makes no sense any more.  I'm outta here

Good puzzle , Sid.

I solved it without even looking at the circles and shades. Thought, hmm, it's a shame that the theme wasn't really necessary to the solve. Went back and read the many moolahs and the PAY BUMP. Appreciated the difficulty of construction.

Then reframed it as, isn't it wonderful to enjoy an activity where the money is superfluous?!



in another kingdom ---
Strands #245
“In my kingdom”
🔵🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🟡🔵
Lost in the supermarket searching for SARQ’s root beer,

I enjoyed this more than most Sunday puzzles. And I really love Sunday puzzles! The cluing today was really fun. I can't tell you which I loved most because I just don't have that much time in a whole day. Every new clue made me laugh. I needed that laugh today, because I am also writing my mom's eulogy; her funeral is in a few days and doing the puzzles today was a nice break. In our family, doing puzzles together on a Sunday was a ritual while I was growing up. In later years, after she and Dad moved to Florida, I would sometimes call her to help me finish a puzzle. She would do them all, when she was younger...cryptoquotes, jumbles, XWDs, anything that came her way.

I think she stopped doing them somewhere around age 98. Her eyesight wasn't as good. By age 100, I could still ask her to help me with them, but it wasn't the same. She lived to over 103, long enough to influence a few generations of word and puzzle lovers. 

So I dedicate today's win to her, because I suspect that somewhere, she was helping me with it, whether I knew it or not. 

Thanks Mom.

Okay... so THAT happened?!

FWIW... I am a longtime NYT solver who started in print
and moved over to digital during the pandemic.
I normally only do Th/F/S/S puzzles.
I don't monitor my streaks or my timings.
And I enjoy reading this column and comments
on occasion and used to dabble in Rex's world.

This is my first comment ever... here.

I enjoyed this one and finished it in one sitting.
I regularly do the xword over 2 breakfast sessions.

"Having said that..." 

I saw the puzzle title.
And I saw the note about the shaded squares.
I saw NO NOTE about the circles?

So I went about my business and after
a little (ok... a LOT of) trouble up in the NE corner...
COMPLETED IT!

I still had NO IDEA what the circles meant
or how they played into solving?

I then read the WORDPLAY column which
confused me even further.

And then read many of the reader COMMENTS.
This occasionally at least reassures me that
I am not alone...

Sooo... different words for money?
With each one getting a BUMP up
on one letter by one row?

Which I only saw AFTER.
And which didn't help in solving?

Hmmm...

I have always LOVED the so called 
egg ZZZ tra hour of sleep 
the DST fall back gives me.

But seem ZZZ I may have been sleepwalking 
through this pu ZZZ le?

Am I even typing this comment?

Some nambuli ZZZ t I am?!

But fun pun the le ZZZ t!
What a slog. What happened  to the fun, the delight, the joy?
For three beautiful minutes this afternoon, I thought Shaq had launched a bestselling root beer. Thanks for that.

Enjoyed the puzzle. Led astray by my own mistakes but nice aha moments when the crosses helped me fix the errors. Did a couple  of Googles. Didn't understand the purpose of the funky money word solves to the rest of the puzzle, but whatever. However... Three times this week, including yesterday and today, the android phone app is saying that it's not solved. Checked the answer key and everything is correctly filled in. So Frustrating!!
Again, kindly requesting that people reference their comments with the Across or Down Clue #, so we can find their concern more rapidly - Thanks.

It's like déjà vu all over again.  CONGRUENCy instead of CONGRUENCE cost me over 20 minutes and drove me close to throwing in the towel, but since I did not know Jemison's first name, and the crosses seemed OK, it took me awhile to think to try MAE instead of MAy.

GUTENBERG invented movable type, according to legend. But the printing press with fixed pages was already in use. 

I believe that GUTENBERG was inspired by the Chinese, who already had movable type.
C'mon, maybe this type of challenge could be a separate puzzle???  I'm passing, again, on this one.  Somebody is trying too hard.
Can someone explain the blue and yellow ball grids? Thanks.

@Mike 

If you wanted to recharge your sterling reputation, you could teller a thing or two!

@bps 
Excellent return!  But perhaps you should just withdraw.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@Mike 
I was going to criticize your CD pun, but I'll just leave it a loan.
@Robco I laughed out loud when I got the juggling answer. It’s the kind of useless trivia I appreciate knowing. For more on the topic: https://youtu.be/7RDfNn7crqE?si=WZOLLn2YQ4E2vM2i

@Justin

I would say Sid really went for the JUGULAR with that clue.  Thanks, Justin, for the YouTube clip on the world record holder for balls in the air.

I got stymied for a while because I went with PANHANDLE instead of PENINSULA.
That was even after I got the “money” theme when I looked up KALA to find that was a Hawaiian term for “money”.  (I also never heard of KALE as a term for money.)

Michael,

I like a running theme too, 
which is why I really enjoyed 
finding the seven pay raises 
as I was solving the puzzle.
@Barry Ancona I guess the theme within the puzzle went over my head. I didn't see any of that.

@Cat Lady Margaret

Kale and dough definitely had me thinking pizza as well, especially since the largest commercial buyer of kale used to be Pizza Hut, for decorating their salad bar (or so I’ve heard).

@Min, MOOLAH unfortunately wasn’t possible, but an early version of the theme set did include THER(MOPLA)STIC -> MO(O)LA — which I thought was fun. 

Someone who solved an early draft of this puzzle also commented on SCREWING. I guess I should’ve anticipated the interest in this word … after all, it’s the only one of the six classical simple machines that effectively converts torque to linear displacement. Pretty special! :)
@Min, this is one of those times when a joke I’m absolutely certain would have killed in person fell flat over text … that’s on me. Don’t worry, I’m definitely smiling along with you!

@Sid Sivakumar 
How gracious you are! That is a quality that is much appreciated.  Still smiling - thanks.
@Sid Sivakumar I thought the simple machine joke was funny.

Now I’m wondering if there’s a word for the kind of wordplay where a word like screwing is used in a way which is not risqué at all, but it still makes people clutch their pearls reflexively because they’re used to seeing it in a different context.
@Min It's referring to turning the head of a screw. Nothing risqué about it

@Steven M. 
I know that.  I guess one's sense of humor doesn't always come through. I tried. :)

@Sid Sivakumar 
That particular answer came to me without hesitation (too many home-improvement projects?) ...and took me all the way back to student teaching (1969) when I taught a class about Simple Machines.  Wrapping the inclined plane around a rod...do we even know what culture came up with that?  However, the 4th-graders did not get into the torque and linear displacement, for some reason....

Thanks for thinking of me, Anita. Glad you enjoyed the puzzle, and nice work picking up on the theme early! 

It might be another stretch before I have more puzzles in the Times. But the great news about the Super Mega is that it doubles as a crossword calendar for an entire year (if you solve exactly two clues per day).

Barry, I appreciate the kind words! At the risk of jinxing things: it looks like my thesis defense will be in 2025, and then I’ll head back to clinics for two more years of medical school. I used to struggle to convey the concept of a “time void,” but the pandemic seems to have given everyone an idea of what that’s like. More or less, that’s a reasonable way to think about the timeline of an MD/PhD program. Thanks for checking in on me!

@Sid Sivakumar 
I agree with Barry, this was a fun puzzle.  Also, I've been enjoying your book of minis "to do while you drink your brew".   (The 'brew' is tea.)

Bill,

I can see "many solvers" not being sure 
of the last letter of the term at 86 Across, 
but MAE the astronaut has been in the grid 
14 times in the past five years. I think 
she should be in your orbit.

Vaer,

You describe the original Natick.

Even its originator broadened the meaning.

At this point, it seems to mean 
"two crossing words I didn't know, 
or knew but couldn't spell."

@Vaer 

I'd argue that that crossing is uninferable, as both May and Mae are/can be names, and congruence and congruency are both nouns that could complete 86A

Barry,

You can rest assured,

I will remember her name,

on the fifteenth time

@Barry Ancona

A word about Gutenberg—I forgot whose list this was (maybe the History channel) but Gutenberg was named number 1 of the top most influential/consequential people of the millennia from 1000-2000, and for good reason. His invention sparked all kinds of changes in the world, the Reformation, the Renaissance, the Enlightenment. Before that literacy was very low and reserved for only the elite because books and scrolls were very expensive to make and own. One could argue that the invention itself was bound to happen one way or the other and by no means was Gutenberg the smartest or most creative guy who ever lived—but he came up with the printing press and it changed the world dramatically.

*rage

Why does autocorrect either do silly things or not catch them at all?






Emu knows.

@Andrzej 

Odessa TX is one of the cities where I have friends since I visited it on my American travels many lifetimes ago (i.e. the 1990s). So as soon as I had a couple of crosses it was a gimme. 

As for the spelling of the original Ukrainian Odes(s)a, the version with ss seems to ensure that it gets closer to the original pronunciation. Otherwise it might be pronounced "Odeeza" in English. Since Ukrainian uses the Cyrillic alphabet there's always the dilemma
* Do you use a traditional transliteration, even if it is no longer considered politically correct or opportune? (E.g. Kiev) 
* Do you follow an official transliteration system even if it does not result in something that can easily be pronounced correctly? (e.g. Zelenskyy) 
* Do you use a spelling that leads a reader of the target language to get the pronunciation sort of right without having to overthink? (E.g. Selenski, the German transliteration of Mr. Zelenskyy). 

It's especially tricky when a traditional transliteration could lead to the assumption that ownership is disputed or illegally claimed. German-language media still use the traditional Russian-sounding Kiew (yep, with a W here), but have easily adopted Luhansk (over Russian Lugansk), Dnipro (over Dnjepropetrowsk) or Lwiw (over Lwow), even though the latter are all still in everybody's old high school atlas. Probably because it's much harder to change a name everybody knows than one nobody has ever heard.

@Andrzej I think Texas is a bit of a mis-direct for those who live in the states as well. I know there's a Moscow Idaho, and there's a Paris Texas. And yes, as Warren says, there are a ton of names here borrowed from the old world.

@Andrzej As a recovering Texan (I grew up there, but moved away over 30 years ago), I can give you a little insight about why it was clued to the Texas city.  The twin cities of Odessa and Midland (about 20 miles apart) each have a population of just over 100,000.  They are in sparsely-populated west Texas, and exist primarily because they sit in the center of a huge oil-producing region.  They are awash in money, and one of the ways this has manifested is through obscenely-over-funded American football teams at their high schools.  They have stadiums to rival large college programs, all the newest equipment, and a large staff of coaches, trainers, etc.  The football games have become the cultural focus of both communities.  This has created an epic rivalry between two schools in particular -- Odessa High School and Permian Basin High School (in Midland).  This rivalry was used as the model for the fictional American television series called Friday Night Lights (so named because high school games are almost always played on Friday evenings).  When the TV show became a huge hit, Odessa, Texas suddenly became known on a national level here in the States.  So for American solvers, the way it was clued makes total sense.
